comments.commentBody: I started piano at 45. I'm 53 now and still can't really play anything. So I think piano is elusive at any age. Don't feel bad!

I just retired after 40 years of public service at age 60.  I ran the race all alone, no help from parents or husband.  Young women, my advice is plan your finances as if you are in control of your destiny.  Keep your own money and live below your means.  Save money anyway you can and purchase your own home as soon as you can.  I bought a fixer upper and watched it appreciate 4X what I paid in 15 years.  Now I am retired totally debt free.
Not sure what you are talking about here - with the exception of the first pairing in the photos, both older and younger people are smiling in all of them.

comments.userLocation: Fair Verona where we lay our scene
comments.commentBody:
The biggest mistake a lot of people make is carelessly marrying just because they fall in love. Most of the anguish I see people go through all comes from stupid choices of a partner.

If there is ONE area that you need to ask your family and/or friends' advice, whether to marry this particular person in the one time you need to listen to people.
Number Two: moving too often. You can blow a third of your take-home pay by taking out new mortgages on new houses.

comments.userLocation: Fair Verona where we lay our scene
comments.commentBody: I tell people never to get involved in fads just to be cool - like stupid stuffed toy fads, the climate scare with ZERO studies that can be repeated, bottled water bought at retail, or - the dumbest - borrowing money to have a new car.

comments.userLocation: Fair Verona where we lay our scene
comments.commentBody: Spend high school earning a good scholarship so you don't leave college with debt it will take you a decade or to to pay off. Plus, that will keep you out of trouble.

Actually, culinary sophistication is one of our real problems. Many Americans are overweight because of their diets. I am horrified that Mr. Bruni disses President Obama about his snack of seven almonds. His athleticism and his cool were in part due to the excellence of his diet. Michelle Obama did the whole country a favor with her garden, carefully planned meals, and her athleticism. Although the Congress is trying to kill (or has killed) her work to have healthy school lunches, at least some children have profited by them and may grow up eating what will make the Affordable Care Act affordable.

You are what you eat!
If you are a healthy hetero woman go abut 15 yrs younger for a guy.  Then you will have similar energy level and not be a nursemaid in the older yrs.

I hope young people are reading these comments, because they are better than the story, though admittedly the story alots only about two tweets to each retiree, and here we can stretch out a bit.

My advice to young people is to figure out what you hold most important and most dear, which often is not sufficiently lucrative, but get to work on it anyway. For money, find a good day job.

Save as much as you can, so that you can "retire" as soon you can.

Then you can work on what you want in the way you want, and you will feel the liberation of being able to completely devote your time and energy to what you care about most.
That God Is one of us and that being yourself, allowing Him to love others through who you are, remains the greatest contribution anyone can make to this old dying world.

If you marry, marry for love, not "love" (passion). Passion will wane in short order so make sure that you love the person and are not simply "in love" with your (biased and irrational) idea of who the person is. Accept the flaws of people you love (and people generally) unless they seriously infringe on your well-being. Be kind--you will suffer less and be happier if you are, as will those to whom you are kind. Struggle to behave in ways you will not later regret, because time only goes in one direction--with the exception of the case of memory. So make sure your memories do not haunt you for the rest of your life.

In reply to hen3ry, who seems to say that he is helpless and bitter because other people are oppressing him: I am sorry to hear that things haven't worked out for you, but I am unconvinced that you can't help improve your plight at least a bit. Read the posting by georgiadem; it's an NYT Pick. I believe that almost anyone qualifies for setting up some sort of personal tax-deferred IRA, even if your employers won't contribute to it. This fund will be, for you, "defined" and "fully funded", unless you borrow against it. If you lack willpower, get a financial advisor (not a stock broker) to whom you will have to justify your latest excuse for not contributing to your IRA.
For those who feel they can't save even a little bit, think about how improbable it is that your salary "just happens" to be exactly what your minimum survival wages are. Maybe you can't put in 10% of your salary, but how about 5%? Even 2% will make a measurable difference if you start your fund near the beginning of your career.

Someone, maybe Sheryl Crow? said, "Life is what happens while you're making plans."
Plan and save for retirement, but don't forget to enjoy your work, your family, your life.
How do you know you won't be dead soon?
You are telling the truth!

I had expected some distilled,mellowed advice from retirees.Full of Wisdom....
Instead,what i read was unrequited longings of dreaming to work.
I don't fault the retirees for the answers,the question is what did the journalist ask.
Somewhere the magic of answer was lost in the choice of question,a big question mark.

1. Do all you can, everything, to have a career you will miss every day in your retirement, but don’t go back to it. If you have not had a satisfying career, you cannot have a satisfying retirement.
2. You will need money. Plenty of it is recommended. I think it was Tennessee Williams who observed that you don’t money when you’re young but it sure comes in handy when you’re older.
My Dad always quoted this to me.  "If youth but knew what age would crave, many a penny youth would save.

Never lose your curiosity. Read books you never had time to read, travel to places you've never been, take classes at Osher Lifelong Learning programs, volunteer, and, most of all, adopt a dog who will give you more love than you can imagine and will never desert you.

If the younger Barbara Bush supports the Planned Parenthood, chances are the majority of America supports it. So are gerrymandering and 3 million fewer popular votes going to stand in the way? And what does it say about America
I suspect the older Barbara Bush did too!

He should not have signed off on the Yemen plan. Then again, it should never have gotten to him, past responsible professional review.

What would have happened if Trump had vetoed it? There would have been a chorus of denunciation, that he refused the professional's plan left ready to go by Obama, because he sold out to Russia and its friends in Iran.

Get some "Easy Piano" books with your favorite tunes and plunk away.
Look on line. You'd be surprised what you find. Hal Leonard has tons.
No one cares what you sound like - really....
Music is to be enjoyed, not meant to control you like piano teachers do!
Try it, ok?
MIMA

You've chosen a most admirable craft that will expose you to many things.
Know as many people as you can by listening, patience, recording and reporting. You will come to know yourself.

Happiness, means and health will reorder themselves as you go along.
Always live within your means!

Yes and if possible, live beneath your means. Nowadays people think each kid needs their own bedroom/bathroom and that you need a formal office, shiny new car and fancy vacations, and weddings that cost a fortune.

My generation (boomers) grew up sharing bedrooms or at least sharing a bath (I have a brother). Clothes were bought only twice a year. Toys were only for birthdays & Christmas. No all the time consumerism. My home had little furniture in the living room - a sofa, end tables, and a rocker. My brother and I used it as a playroom.

Eating out was only for special occasions. I enjoyed hand-me-down clothes from a cousin.

If people - especially couples starting out - lived like this, they'd avoid debt and be able to save for the future. And their kids would grow up without an entitlement attitude.

Many might say this advice is old-fashioned and that "kids can't live without this, that or the other" to which I would say - hogwash! My insurance agent has done very well yet his kids got no cars, have had to pay for the extras in college and started saving from the get-go. They are extremely mature and well prepared for their financial future. And adults? You don't need every new toy either!

Because vouchers would only pay a percent. There would be no guarantee with the voucher, unlike Medicare where you know how much of the cost is your responsibility.

Think of someone in their 80's or 90's who has various medical conditions. Now, imagine them going from company to company trying to figure out how much coverage they can get for their voucher.

It's not about choice - we already have choice between Advantage and Medigap policies and the various companies that provide such supplementary coverage.

It's about solid, consistent coverage versus wondering if you can afford to be hospitalized.
